sections.title: Introduction and prerequisites
sections.summary: Lists required tools and frameworks to run the demo locally: Visual Studio, Docker, PowerShell, .NET 9, and Azure CLI.
key_actions: Identify and ensure prerequisites are installed: Visual Studio, Docker, PowerShell, .NET 9, Azure CLI

sections.title: Azure CLI login and resource group creation
sections.summary: Log into Azure using the tenant option to pick the correct subscription, then run a command to create a new resource group (example name shown). The command returns JSON output with resource identifiers.
key_actions: 00:00:13.360 - az login using --tenant option to access the Cloud Advocate tenant
00:00:31.316 - Run command to create a new resource group (example: RGBR CAR 447)
Inspect JSON output for resource IDs and keys

sections.title: Retrieve outputs: endpoints, keys, foundry name
sections.summary: Use CLI commands to get the deployment outputs: keys, endpoint, and the foundry/account name. Copy the foundry name for later steps.
key_actions: Run command to get output and retrieve keys/IDs
Copy the foundry name from the output for configuration

sections.title: Update and run local setup script to obtain connection string
sections.summary: Update a local script with the resource group and account name, paste it into the console, and run it to generate a connection string, endpoint and key. Running the app the first time opens a dashboard that requests the AI Foundry parameter.
key_actions: 00:01:04.000 - Edit the script with resource name and account name
00:01:30.200 - Copy updated script into the console application
00:01:32.000 - Run the script to provision/get the connection string
ui_elements: Local script file (to edit resource/account values)

sections.title: Configure AI Foundry parameter and start application
sections.summary: Paste the AI Foundry parameter into the dashboard when prompted and save it to user secrets so it won't be prompted again. Once configured the application starts and can be used (including semantic search testing).
key_actions: 00:01:45.590 / 00:01:51.045 - Dashboard indicates missing AI Foundry parameter
00:01:56.960 - Paste the foundry value into the dashboard input and save to user secrets
Test browsing the product and run a semantic search to validate integration
ui_elements: Application UI (product browser, semantic search interface)

sections.title: Switching resources and verifying Azure OpenAI deployments
sections.summary: Show how to change which resource the app points to by editing the app host's user secrets (delete/add the AI Foundry line). Then inspect the created Resource Group in the Azure Portal to view Azure OpenAI deployments (chat and embeddings) and retrieve endpoints/keys from the portal.
key_actions: 00:02:23.377 - Open APP host and edit user secrets
00:02:31.440 - Locate AI Foundry entry in user secrets; delete and re-add if changing resources
00:02:39.848 - Open Resource Group in Azure Portal
00:02:49.138 - View Azure OpenAI resources and confirm deployments (e.g., GPT-4o mini for chats and text-embedding, ADI O2 for embeddings)
00:02:57.280 - Retrieve endpoint and key values from portal
ui_elements: Azure OpenAI resource blade (Deployments list, Endpoints, Keys)
